content.question:
Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

<math alttext="H B P B with a positive one charge aqueous, which is yellow, plus O H with a negative one charge aqueous, is in equilibrium with B P B aqueous, which is blue, plus H 2 O liquid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnalign="left" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mtext>H</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>BPB</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>P</mtext><mtext>B</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mtext></mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.8em"></mspace><mi>y</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>w</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="8.5em"></mspace><mi>b</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>u</mi><mi>e</mi></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="H B P B with a positive one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>P</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, the acidified form of bromophenol blue, <math alttext="B P B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BP</mtext><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, is yellow and has a strong absorption peak at a wavelength of <math alttext="440 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>440</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. <math alttext="H B P B with a positive one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>P</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> reacts with hydroxide ions according to the equation above, producing water and <math alttext="B P B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>PB</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, which is blue and has a strong absorption peak at a wavelength of <math alttext="590 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>590 nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

a) Write the <math alttext="K sub e q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> expression for the equilibrium reaction above.

The absorption spectra of an equilibrium mixture of <math alttext="H B P B with a positive one charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>BP</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and ,<math alttext="B P B, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BP</mtext><mtext>B</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> collected at two different temperatures, are shown in the diagram below.

frqParts.text:
Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

<math alttext="H B P B with a positive one charge aqueous, which is yellow, plus O H with a negative one charge aqueous, is in equilibrium with B P B aqueous, which is blue, plus H 2 O liquid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnalign="left" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mtext>H</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>BPB</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>P</mtext><mtext>B</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mtext></mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.8em"></mspace><mi>y</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>w</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="8.5em"></mspace><mi>b</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>u</mi><mi>e</mi></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="H B P B with a positive one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>P</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, the acidified form of bromophenol blue, <math alttext="B P B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BP</mtext><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, is yellow and has a strong absorption peak at a wavelength of <math alttext="440 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>440</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. <math alttext="H B P B with a positive one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>P</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> reacts with hydroxide ions according to the equation above, producing water and <math alttext="B P B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>PB</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, which is blue and has a strong absorption peak at a wavelength of <math alttext="590 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>590 nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

a) Write the <math alttext="K sub e q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> expression for the equilibrium reaction above.

The absorption spectra of an equilibrium mixture of <math alttext="H B P B with a positive one charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>BP</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and ,<math alttext="B P B, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BP</mtext><mtext>B</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> collected at two different temperatures, are shown in the diagram below.

(b) At which wavelength, <math alttext="350 nanometers" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mn>350</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>n</mtext><mtext>m</mtext></mstyle></math> or <math alttext="440 nanometers" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>440</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, are photons with the higher energy absorbed? Justify your answer.
(c) Based on the diagram above, is the forward reaction endothermic or exothermic? Justify your answer in terms of Le Châtelier’s principle.

A calibration plot of the absorbance at wavelength <math alttext="590 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>590</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> versus the concentration of <math alttext="B P B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>PB</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown in the graph below

(d) Based on the best-fit line shown in the graph, what is the approximate absorbance for a solution in which <math alttext="the molar concentration of BPB equals, 2.0 times 10 to the negative 5, molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>PB</mtext><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>2.0</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></msup><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

(e) A student measures the absorbance of a solution of <math alttext="B P B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BP</mtext><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of unknown concentration in order to determine the <math alttext="molar concentration of B P B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>P</mtext><mtext>B</mtext><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the solution using the calibration plot above. If water remains in the cuvette prior to being filled with the solution, how will the estimated molarity compare to the actual <math alttext="molar concentration of B P B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>P</mtext><mtext>B</mtext><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the solution? Explain your reasoning.

Over time, <math alttext="B P B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>PB</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> converts to a colorless molecule in the presence of <math alttext="O H with a negative one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions. To study the rate of the reaction, the student recorded the absorbance of the <math alttext="B P B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BP</mtext><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> solution at <math alttext="590 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>590</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in a <math alttext="0.10 molar N a O H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.10</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi><mtext> </mtext><mtext>Na</mtext><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> solution. The temperature and <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> remain constant throughout the reaction. The results are summarized in the table below.

Time

(<math alttext="in hours" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>hr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>)

Absorbance

0
 0.80

0.50
 0.56

1.00
 0.40

1.50
 0.28

2.00
 0.20

2.50
 0.15

3.00
 0.10

(f) Determine the half-life of the reaction. Include units with your answer.

(g) Explain how the absorbance and time data are consistent with a process that is first order with respect to <math alttext="B P B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BP</mtext><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

A second trial is conducted at the same constant temperature, but with <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext></mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> changed to <math alttext="0.40 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.40</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The observed half-life of the reaction is shorter than for the first trial when <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> was <math alttext="0.10 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.10</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(h) Explain, in term of particle collisions, why the half-life of the reaction decreases when <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is changed from <math alttext="0.10 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.10</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="0.40 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.40</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(i) When <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is changed from <math alttext="0.10 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mn>0.</mn><mrow><mn>10</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="0.40 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.40</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, does the magnitude of <math alttext="delta H naught sub reaction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math>, the enthalpy change of the reaction, increase, decrease, or stay the same? Justify your answer.

In order to prepare the <math alttext="0.100 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.100</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> solution of <math alttext="N a O H, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext><mtext>OH</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, a student follows a procedure with the following steps.
Step 1: Measure out <math alttext="40.0 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40.0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="N a O H, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext><mtext>OH</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.
Step 2: Add the <math alttext="N a O H, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext><mtext>OH</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> to a <math alttext="1000.0 milliliter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1000.0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> volumetric flask that is half-filled with distilled water.
Step 3: Add enough distilled water to bring the volume up to the line on the flask.
(j) The chemical quantities used in the procedure do NOT produce <math alttext="0.100 molar N a O H, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>0.100</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi><mtext> </mtext><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>a</mtext><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>H</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></math>. Describe specifically how they should be changed in order to produce <math alttext="0.100 molar N a O H, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>0.100</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi><mtext> </mtext><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>a</mtext><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>H</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></math>.

(k) Another student is preparing a <math alttext="0.100 molar N a O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.100</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi><mtext> </mtext><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>a</mtext><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> solution using the correct chemical quantities, but notices that some solid remains at the bottom of the volumetric flask. Describe an action that the student should take to ensure that the remaining solid dissolves.

(l) When making the solution above, the student notices that the temperature increases when dissolving <math alttext="N a O H, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>aO</mtext><mtext>H</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in water. In a separate experiment, the student dissolves <math alttext="1.0 mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>mo</mtext><mtext>l</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="N a O H, solid " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>aO</mtext><mtext>H</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in <math alttext="1000. decimal point grams" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1000.</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> each of two different solvents, X and Y. Assuming the enthalpy change is the same regardless of solvent, would the temperature change in solvent X be greater than, less than, or equal to the temperature change in solvent Y? Justify your answer. The specific heat capacities of solvent X and solvent Y are given in the table below.

Solvent
 X
 Y

Specific Heat Capacity

<math alttext="joules per gram degree Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>J</mtext><mo>/</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>g</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

2.53
 2.91

skill.text: 2.C: Identify experimental procedures that are aligned to a scientific question (which may include a sketch of a lab setup).
